body: Handling fullscreen mode is a little bit complicated. Because you can enter and leave it which you could deal with by just reconnecting, but that's not a very good experience. Otherwise you would have to deal with recalculating openings etc. Right now this doesn't seem to be worth the effort.
The speed is now determined by the speed of the users drag

I don't completely understand your question. The two devices have to be in the same network so they can't have the  same IP address.  You have to start the server on your  computer then you enter the address of the server on each device and it should work. If this doesn't solve your problem please explain what you did exactly.

Did you run the `npm install` correctly ?
Did you "Swip" the two devices together correctly ?
Are there any errors in the console when running the server with `npm run particles` ?
Can you touch a single device to create a 'blob' ?

You need to install [webpack](https://github.com/webpack/webpack) as a global depedency. We should add that to the documentation, our bad. 

If you install webpack like this it should work:

``` bash
npm install webpack -g
```

You have to use the IP of your computer on the phones.
Localhost is always the current devices IP. 

e.g.
computer localhost -> 192.168.178.1:3000
phone localhost -> 192.168.178.2:3000

on your computer use localhost:3000
on your phone use 192.168.178.1:3000
server took too long to answer

You have to use the ip of your Computer.

I solved it by installing the right socket.io version manual. Very nice I can see lots of fun applications with this.

This started out as a hackathon project. The inspiration came from [siftables](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JP0w9lZoLwU), which are little programmable diplay squares that can sense how they are position relative to each other. We wanted to build the same kind of applications without having to create custom hardware. It's more intended as an experiment to play around with new ideas rather than solving a concrete problem. If you have some greate ideas for applications let us know. Right now we are not actively working on the project though.

When thinking about some use cases, you are not restricted to using the canvas element (which we used for the demos). You can also use a standard webpage on which you can react on the swipe events. 
A pretty nice "copycat"-project would be the popular bump-app in the browser where you can set up your contact information and exchange them with others with a simple swipe... 
If you're building for example a trading card game, you could add social interactions by giving the players some perks if they exchange cards locally when "swiped" together.
If you have an application like PayPal where you can send money to friends, you could increase the usability for the customers by giving them some kind of physical interaction (the swipe).

There are really a lot of possibilities, since it's built as a library you could integrate it with a lot of different applications and give them some nice unique features, it's not restricted to games.
